Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all residential leases include an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified at Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14, which requires landlords to ensure that tenants can use and enjoy rented premises free from substantial interference by the landlord or others acting under the landlord’s control.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in Chelsea District Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, § 3, as the underlying events giving rise to this action occurred in Chelsea, Massachusetts.

Warsowe v. Mosher, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 91.raw_text: Warsowe v. Mosher, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 91 (1985)
Warsowe v. Mosher, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 91.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that landlords are liable for breaching the covenant of quiet enjoyment where they fail to remedy dangerous or disruptive conditions affecting the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Warsowe v. Mosher, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 91.support_reasoning: This decision is a zoning/use-classification case about whether a salt-import operation is a permitted ‘commercial dock’ under a municipal zoning ordinance. It does not involve a landlord-tenant relationship, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or landlord liability for failing to remedy dangerous or disruptive conditions. Therefore it does not support the stated proposition about Massachusetts landlords’ liability for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Warsowe v. Mosher, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 91.relevant_excerpt: 1. The principal question is whether the use contemplated by Eastern for its waterfront site should properly be characterized under the zoning ordinance as a commercial dock (as the plaintiffs contend) or as a wholesale business storage and distribution area (as the city contends). Both uses are permitted in an Industrial Waterfront District under §§ 4.1.3(18) and 4.1.4, respectively, of the ordinance.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that landlords are liable for breaching the covenant of quiet enjoyment where they fail to remedy dangerous or disruptive conditions affecting the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies and discusses the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment in the context of a landlord’s failure to remedy serious, disruptive and unsanitary flooding conditions that interfered with the tenant’s use of the apartment. The court explains that § 14 and the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment cover substantial interferences with the tenant’s tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, including failure to maintain sanitary, watertight premises, and holds the landlord liable under § 14 on that basis. Although the $10,000 quiet-enjoyment damages award is vacated as duplicative, the opinion affirms liability and attorneys’ fees under the quiet enjoyment statute for failure to remedy dangerous/disruptive conditions affecting use and enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that landlords are liable for breaching the covenant of quiet enjoyment where they fail to remedy dangerous or disruptive conditions affecting the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court directly applies and explains the Massachusetts covenant of quiet enjoyment statute, G.L. c. 186, § 14, and holds that a landlord may be liable where its omissions allow dangerous, disruptive criminal activity (drug dealing, threats, violence) to seriously interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment of the premises. The court reverses summary judgment on the quiet enjoyment claim, expressly recognizing that failure to take available measures to remove unlawful actors from common areas can constitute a breach. This squarely supports landlord liability for failing to remedy dangerous or disruptive conditions that impair tenants’ quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that landlords are liable for breaching the covenant of quiet enjoyment where they fail to remedy dangerous or disruptive conditions affecting the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where a dangerous or highly disruptive condition substantially interferes with tenants’ use and enjoyment, and the landlord has the ability and opportunity to control or remedy it but fails to do so. The court emphasizes that liability can arise from what the landlord “failed to do, or…permitted to be done,” and explicitly rejects a nonfeasance/malfeasance distinction in such circumstances. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts courts hold landlords liable for failing to remedy disruptive conditions affecting quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that landlords are liable for breaching the covenant of quiet enjoyment where they fail to remedy dangerous or disruptive conditions affecting the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reaffirms that negligent failure to repair known defects or dangerous conditions can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. In doing so, it cites and relies on a line of prior Massachusetts cases (Simon, Darmetko, Dorgan, Cruz, Doe) holding landlords liable where they failed to remedy conditions that interfered with tenants’ use and enjoyment. Although the specific holding is that a bare statutory lead paint violation is not enough without fault, the case clearly endorses the broader proposition that landlords are liable under § 14 when they negligently fail to correct dangerous or disruptive conditions affecting quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….
